title: Monday, 4th July, 2016
bodyHTML:

PM

Do give us feedback if you came along on Friday

PM

PM

PM

PM

11:05 am
BE

Yes, though the longer term picture is less clear and one would expect the 10yr to price in a little of that uncertainty.

PM

of course, yes

PM

See Morgan Stanley say UK rates going down to 10bps

11:06 am
BE

We had commenters on Friday calling for Carney to be sacked for saying that rates would have to rise and also have to fall. As if that's not just a statement of fact.

PM

hehehe

BE

Emergency brake cut to 10bps or wherever. Then -- most likely -- a steeper tightening over the following decade or two than was assumed before the UK electorate decided to drive us into a wall.

11:07 am
BE

Makes sense to me. Not to some commenters though. W'evs.

PM

Let me jsut share this Morgan Stanley stuff

PM

Pre-referendum guidance: Prior to the referendum, the Bank of England provided guidance - see for instance the June Minutes - on the likely impact of the referendum on the economy, and its response:
- Impact. The MPC argued that inflation was likely to rise in the near term, as a result of the passthrough from a weaker GBP, while the rise in uncertainty was likely to hit demand and growth.
-Response. The MPC argued that the policy response would not be automatic, given higher inflation and weaker growth, and would rely on the relative magnitudes of the impacts on sterling, demand and supply. They implied that they wanted to see the impact on the economy before responding, which would require waiting to get some data.

11:08 am
PM

MS call up to now: Our interpretation was that this cautious data-dependent guidance implied that the August 4 Inflation Report meeting was likely too early to act. Since they would prefer to make any policy response in the context of revised forecasts, we previously thought the November 3 Inflation Report meeting was the most likely date for policy action in the case of a vote to Leave the EU.

PM

Greater policy instability puts premium on early action: We see multiple sources of uncertainty after the vote to leave, which underpin a wide span of possible outcomes ( see UK Economics | EU Referendum: Out into the Unknown (24 Jun 2016). The political circumstances after the vote in particular have turned out to be very challenging, including the Prime Minister resigning, unexpected developments in the Conservative leadership campaign, a standoff between the leader of the Labour Party and many Labour Party MPs, and a fresh push for Scottish independence from the Scottish nationalists. Against this background, Carney argued in his speech yesterday that there has been a particularly high level of "policy uncertainty" in the UK this year. We think this implies a case for early action as a signal of intent, to reinforce confidence in policy frameworks, reduce uncertainty and support adjustment.

PM

Strong guidance from the MPC: Yesterday, Carney said that he thought easier policy would “likely be required in the summer”, i.e. at the July or August meeting, and promised a "host of measures" to deal with the "post-traumatic stress" of the vote to Leave. This was reinforced by his briefing today that the FPC would cut the countercyclical buffer back to zero for the banks on 5th July.
Precautionary approach: We think the MPC is acting on a forward-looking precautionary principle, rather than responding to past data. The economy has taken a hit, but it is not clear how severe the impact will be. If the economy has been badly impacted, then an early response will be more effective. If the economy has not been badly impacted, then any easing measures can be unwound at little long-term cost. Furthermore, confidence will be one of the main things that will determine how badly impacted the economy will be. Therefore to the extent that the MPC can shore up confidence, they may help prevent a worse economic outcome. On this reasoning, it is better to act early and forcefully, and review later.

11:08 am
PM

Rates the key instrument of policy: We have high conviction that the first and main instrument of easing will be interest rates, since the MPC has described rates since the November 2015 Inflation Report as the "active marginal instrument for monetary policy". In 2009, the MPC did not cut below 50 bps, partly because of concern that the banks were inadequately capitalised and had excessive exposure to tracker mortgages. Now that the banks are better capitalised and the use of tracker mortgages has been reduced, the MPC has suggested that the Bank rate can be cut.

PM

10 is the floor, we think: The MPC has been reluctant to cut rates to negative levels, on the grounds that they see negative rates as a risk to financial stability, and unsustainable for an extended period of time, and therefore not fully credible. We think that they would prefer to see policy rate staying modestly positive, and we therefore see 10 bp as the effective floor for policy rates.
Front-loading the response: We do not have high conviction about the magnitude of the cut, or the exact timing, but, on balance, we think that the MPC will want to use its scope to ease via interest rates to the full extent, and lower rates for the time being to the effective floor. We expect a standard 25 bp cut at the July 14 meeting, as an initial move, with a further 15 bp, backed by the new forecasts prepared for the August Inflation Report, at the August 4 meeting.
Will the MPC all agree? Some in the MPC may favour sticking to the cautious guidance provided before the referendum, particularly given the relatively orderly movements in markets, and the sharp fall in gilt yields, which amounts to an effective easing. However, we also think the MPC would seek to act in an unified manner. On balance, we would expect to see broad support for the initial cut, as a supportive action in response to the "traumatic" impact of the vote to Leave, but we see a more finely balanced decision on the second move down to 10 bps.

PM

Sorry, a lot to read there

11:09 am
PM

Last par

PM

If rates are maxed out, what options are left? If more easing is required down the line - and that will depend on how the Brexit shock plays out - we would expected it to be provided by £50bn QE and fiscal policy at the autumn statement. Here, the abolition after the vote to Leave (see BBC) of the target of achieving a fiscal surplus by 2020 gives additional scope for policy action. We have highlighted the possibility of a helicopter money experiment , if rates are at the lower bound, fiscal policy is constrained and the economy weakens from a negative shock (see UK Economics: Can Helicopter Money Really Fly? (26 May 2016).

Clarkson vs the Baltic Dry, normalised to the start of 2009.

11:15 am

11:16 am
BE

Here's Panmure to help us out.

BE

Clarkson has issued a trading update highlighting the deteriorating business
conditions it faces and anticipating materially weaker profits YoY in 2016. We
now anticipate recovery to be delayed into 2017. We cut our FY16 clean PBT
forecast by 21% to £43.1m and amend future forecasts; effectively our former
FY17 forecast has become our FY18 forecast. We shade our 2016 dividend
forecast by 2p per share but leave prospective dividend forecasts unchanged.
We reduce our target price to 2,550p per share (from 2,800p). We believe
Clarkson is well positioned to leverage the recovery when it comes. The
company should have very substantial additional distribution potential from
2018, once the Platou loan note has been repaid. We remain Buyers.

BE

 ClarkSea index down 30%, capital markets subdued. Business conditions in
Clarkson’s markets have continued to deteriorate with the ClarkSea index down 30%
YoY and down 33% HoH. Despite benefiting from weaker sterling, profits are under
pressure, notwithstanding the strength of Clarkson’s underlying business
performance.
 Recovery deferred. Voyage activity looks set to grow this year by some 2% YoY. So
the main pressure on rates is from over-supply which is in the process of being
worked off. Shipping is a cyclical business, so the timing of recovery is uncertain but
we believe it is prudent to assume that it is likely to be delayed into 2017.
 Target price of 2,550p per share. Our revised target price of 2,550p reflects the
approximately £1 per share reduction in free cash flow for 2016-18 that we now
forecast and would put Clarkson on the same P/E and dividend yield in 2018 that it
has traded at on average over the 2012-15 period.
 Upside potential. Should shipping markets start to recover in 2017, as we expect, and
shareholders become more confident about the scale of potential cash for
distribution in 2018, once the Platou loan note has been fully repaid, then we believe
that Clarkson could well trade above our revised target price. However, markets may
take a more cautious view initially until it becomes clearer that business conditions
are improving.

11:18 am

John Menzies PLC (MNZS:LSE): Last: 562.50, up 7.5 (+1.35%), High: 565.50, Low: 555.00, Volume: 6.52k
11:20 am
PM

Shareholder Value Management AG, based in Frankfurt (Germany), follows the principles of value investing, looking to invest in securities with prices that are unjustifiably low relative to the intrinsic values of the underlying businesses. The company advises various investment vehicles with a total of 1.7bn EUR in assets, allocated primarily to small and midcap companies in Europe. Shareholder Value Management AG takes the role of a stable financial investor, engaging actively with entrepreneurs, business owners and management teams to contribute to long term value creation for shareholders.

BE

Moneysupermarket.Com Group PLC (MONY:LSE): Last: 245.10, down 29.9 (-10.87%), High: 271.90, Low: 243.50, Volume: 1.27m

11:27 am
BE

Barclays' concerns are similar but different. Let me get the front page up.

BE

..............

BE

We have been positive on Moneysupermarket since initiating last year (see No need to
shop around, 12 Apr 2015). But the layers of uncertainty in the story have been
building in the last nine months, most notably from elevated competition. The
outcome of the UK referendum and a forthcoming expected recession in the UK is
now a new concern, and one uncertainty too many for us. We do see areas of
cyclicality in the Moneysupermarket business model, notably in Travel Supermarket,
travel insurance in Insurance, and financial products in Money. At this point, it is hard
to model the precise impact of the downturn on numbers – our first attempt is to put
through an 8% EPS downgrade in 2017E. But we do see clear risks to consensus for
next year if a recession bites. There are still positives in the story: a likely special
dividend at end 2016 (leaving the shares on a 7% dividend yield, 50/50
regular/special), and benefits from the capex programme to come through. But we no
longer have confidence in positive forecast momentum, and on 17.7x 12 month
forward P/E post EPS downgrade, the shares are only slightly below the historical
average vs the FTSE250. We feel that this does already capture the risks. But we
struggle to argue for a rerating from here and therefore downgrade to Equal Weight,
lowering our PT to 260p on lower forecasts and a higher discount rate to our DCF.

11:28 am
BE

Our first attempt to rebase our model to a UK recession: In 2009, Moneysupermarket
saw a revenue decline of 24%. That was a particularly severe recession, impacting
credit availability and the mix of the group has changed since. So this time we still think
top line growth can be achieved (we now have +4% in 2017) but we still cut EPS by 8%
in 2017 and 7% in 2018 as we rebase our model to a recessionary environment.

BE

Valuation looking fair: On new numbers, Moneysupermarket is on 17.7x 12 month
forward P/E, c,10% above historical levels on an absolute basis and c.5% below relative
to the FTSE250. Given pre existing risks around competition and now new risks around
UK macro, we struggle argue for a rerating from here.

BE

1H results preview: Our downgrade is not a call on Q2 trends – we expect decent
results. We model 2% insurance growth in Q2, 20% in Money, 25% in Home Services
and -25% in Travel. Key outlook points to focus on are 1) management expectations on
FY16E (they were happy with £107m of EBITA at Q1), 2) expectations on marketing in
2H (we model in an extra £5m y/y of paid search in 2016E, at top of guidance), and 6)
uses of cash for M&A vs dividends (we model a 10p special dividend at end 2016E).

11:29 am
BE

So, the recession forecasts are based around what happened in 2008.

BE

And MoneySupermarket's feltcollaredsource argues that it's a different company now.

PM

Busy chap, the MoneySupermarket feltcollaredsource

11:30 am
BE

He is. We're in regular correspondence.

BE

Their assertion is (a) the UK enters recession and (b) that recession is bad for the Moneysupermarket. One thing to consider on the second point is, should the UK enter a recession, people are likely to shop around and switch products to make the most of their money, which would be beneficial to MoneySupermarket.

And as Barclays do state MoneySupermarket is now a significantly different business now, including for example through its ownership of Martin Lewis’s MoneySavingExpert.

BE

So make of that what you wish.

11:34 am
BE

We do have a Friday evening stinker from GKP though.

Gulf Keystone Petroleum Ltd (GKP:LSE): Last: 4.10, down 0.75 (-15.46%), High: 4.75, Low: 3.55, Volume: 17.21m
BE

Still 4p! Why?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!!?!??!?!??!?!?

11:35 am
BE

So, just before RNS closed on Friday, this dropped ....

BE

Further to the Company's RNS of 14 June 2016, Gulf Keystone announces today that the current Standstill Agreement between the Ad Hoc Committee of holders of the Notes and the Bonds and the Company expired on 1 July 2016 at 5pm BST and has not been extended.

The Company is currently discussing the terms of an agreement with certain restricted members of the Ad Hoc Committee and other stakeholders. These restructuring discussions remain ongoing notwithstanding the expiration of the Standstill Agreement.

At this stage, the Company does not intend to make the April 2016 Coupon Payments. The holders of not less than one-quarter of the principal amount of the Notes or the Bonds, as the case may be, outstanding, may request the relevant Trustee to declare the principal amount of the Notes or the Bonds, as the case may be, immediately due and payable. Whilst these coupons remain unpaid, and absent a new Standstill Agreement executed by 75% of the principal amount of each of the Notes and the Bonds, an Event of Default will subsist under both the Notes and the Bonds.

A further announcement will be made in due course.

BE

Then, to fill in all the gaps you'd hope shareholders would be given equal access to, Danny Forston of the Sunday Times had a debrief from someone familiar with the situation.

11:36 am
PM

goodness me

BE

..... doesn't seem to be on Factiva, weirdly. You may need to dig a copy out of the recycling.

PM

Can you remember the gist?

11:38 am
BE

Oh, no, wait! Got it.

PM

(Cos I didn't buy the paper)

BE

ONE-TIME stock market darling Gulf Keystone Petroleum is close to a deal with creditors that will wipe out its investors but allow the stricken producer to survive.

The company, which pumps oil from a big field in Kurdistan, northern Iraq, was worth £3.6bn in 2012. The plunging price of crude, Kurdistan's inability to pay for oil, the incursion of Isis terrorists into Kurdish territory and Gulf Keystone's huge debts combined to cause its near-collapse. As of Friday, its stock traded at 4.85p, 99% below its high.

The company is this weekend haggling over the final details of a two-part rescue plan. Creditors have agreed to write off most of the $575m (£430m) due next year as part of a debt-for-equity swap that will leave them as majority owners of the shares.

Gulf Keystone is also expected to launch an equity fundraising to bring in about $40m to bolster its balance sheet. It is thought that a core of institutional investors have agreed to back the financing. The final figure is being negotiated this weekend. The investors are betting that Gulf Keystone, shorn of its crippling debt burden, could recover strongly. Its Shaikan field produces 37,000 barrels a day, the Kurdish regional government has begun to make more regular payments and a new management team has banished the boardroom in-fighting that once plagued the producer. Gulf Keystone declined to comment.

11:39 am
BE

Remember, that's Mr Fortson speaking to someone who's likely to consider the rescue rights issue the best possible outcome.

BE

And it's still 4p.

J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 234.20, down 1.9 (-0.80%), High: 237.50, Low: 233.80, Volume: 1.43m
11:46 am
BE

undefined
BE

Otherwise on retail, there seems to be a rash of bad feeling towards M&S all of a sudden.

11:46 am
PM

oh dear, why?

BE

I don't know specifically. But the couple of brokers who were still on buy ratings post the last profit warning are no longer on buy ratings.

BE

Both Deutsche and Investec decide to chuck in the towel this morning.

11:47 am
BE

A coincidence of timing, I guess.

BE

Investec first.

BE

A weak Q1 is anticipated given recent industry sales data. It is too early to quantify the future profit impact of Brexit from a slower demand perspective. As market leader, M&S has historically struggled to buck industry trends. We cut FY18e by 10% to reflect currency impact on COGS & lower LFLs and now forecast 2 years of profit decline. M&S is in a better position vs pre-Financial Crisis with self-help opportunities & strong cash generation, but it is difficult to see profit growth in a weaker environment. Cut to HOLD (from Buy).

A weak Q1 performance is expected. It is well documented that the clothing sector has had a difficult year-to-date, with April particularly weak. Debenhams said on its Q3 call (22nd June) that industry sales were down 4% over the last 12 weeks, which is a similar period to M&S’ 1Q. We forecast Clothing & Home sales down 5% (4Q16 -2.7%), with flat food sales (4Q16 flat). M&S reports on 7th July.
Market more concerned over currency and impact of Brexit on medium-term consumer demand. Management’s FY17 gross margin Clothing & Home (C&H) guidance of +50bps to +100bps was given when the USD:GBP was trading at c.$1.45 and included a 70bps headwind at that point. We estimate a 5c move in the USD:GBP equates to c.80bps impact on the C&H gross margin. With FY17 mostly hedged, recent currency moves are expected to impact FY18.
FY18e PBT cut by 10% to reflect currency c.$1.35 & weaker demand. INVe now expects a flat FY18e gross margin (prev +120bps) and nudges down C&H LFLs to -2% (prev -1%). We suspect management would be able to mitigate some of the currency effect and put nothing in for a positive currency effect on international earnings as some restructuring may be announced at 1H17.
Downgrade to HOLD from Buy given uncertainty over the medium-term demand environment and that we now forecast 2 years of profit decline, with the recent move in exchange rates expected to fully impact FY18E estimates. Valuation (CY17e PE 10.9x) is not particularly demanding with the surplus cashflow and dividend yield (5.9% ex special) offering support to the shares. TP based on a 10% discount to the average sector 10-year forward PE cut to 315p from 460p, reflecting downgrades and peer group de-rating.

11:48 am
BE

And Deutsche ..... wider sector take.

BE

Following the UK’s referendum vote for Brexit we lower sector UK earnings by
c.10% to reflect weaker consumer demand and generally negative currency
effects. Target Prices have been rebased around our revised forecasts. We
make seven recommendation changes, upgrading Inchcape to Buy to sit
alongside Next and Dufry as our top picks. We downgrade Asos to Hold and
upgrade Yoox Net a Porter and Zalando to Buy after their diverging share price
performance, and downgrade M&S, Steinhoff and Showroomprive to Hold.
Visibility is low, but we see selective value in the sector.
ollowing the UK’s referendum vote for Brexit we lower sector UK earnings by
c.10% to reflect weaker consumer demand and generally negative currency
effects. Target Prices have been rebased around our revised forecasts. We
make seven recommendation changes, upgrading Inchcape to Buy to sit
alongside Next and Dufry as our top picks. We downgrade Asos to Hold and
upgrade Yoox Net a Porter and Zalando to Buy after their diverging share price
performance, and downgrade M&S, Steinhoff and Showroomprive to Hold.
Visibility is low, but we see selective value in the sector.

BE

As the dust settles following the vote, we recalibrate our view of the outlook
for general retailers. The three main drivers are: [1] Consumer demand: our
central case is a fairly benign Brexit scenario, with UK private consumption still
growing, but at a slower rate, as per Deutsche Bank’s economic forecasts; [2]
Currency: we factor in the translational effects of spot currencies (positive for
some like ASOS, Inchcape, Kingfisher and Inditex). We consider the theoretical
higher transaction costs from US dollar sourcing, though expect much of these
to be offset by sector-wide price rises; [3] Equity risk premium: Brexit
represents the beginning of a new period of material political uncertainty for
financial markets. Our strategists see a rise in the cost of equity of 100bps and
we factor 9% into our target prices. We also consider a number of other
factors, including supply, pensions and M&A.

11:49 am
BE

On average our forecast cut for UK retailers in 2016 is c.4% and for 2017 is
c.10%, though this masks a wide spread which reflects differing levels of
exposure and operational gearing. In most instances share prices across the
sector have fallen further than our earnings cuts. We do not expect, in our
base case, sector balance sheets to come under pressure.

BE

We are not expecting a downturn similar to the global financial crisis, rather
more like the slowdown in 2011-12. We make three observations: [1] Retail is
early cycle sector and the near-term for the sector could be choppy until
trading trends are clearer. There was a rapid trading deterioration following the
Northern Rock shock in 2007; [2] Consumer behaviour is likely to change, with
a higher savings ratio (despite low interest rates) and potential trading down as
prices rise; [3] The retail sector is a diverse collection of stocks with different
demand/ supply drivers, and different operational/financial gearing.

BE

We upgrade Inchcape to Buy and see this as a top pick alongside Next and
Dufry. We downgrade ASOS to Hold and upgrade YNAP and Zalando to Buy.
We also downgrade to Hold M&S, Showroomprive and Steinhoff. On our new
forecasts the UK sector trades on a 2016 P/E of 13.7x. Our valuation approach
is usually DCF-based, except where multiple-based or SOTP approaches are
more appropriate. Main upside risks include less of a consumer slowdown
than we now model, successful mitigation of currency pressures, competitor
withdrawals and business change programmes. Downside risks could come
from a reversal of these factors or (eventually) from rising interest rates.

11:49 am

11:50 am
BE

undefined
PM

11:51 am
PM

omg smile

BE

Ditto.

PM

How many hours did you live blog the thing on Friday?

11:51 am
PM

(It was v good, btw, great service)

BE

BE

Risks surrounding commercial real estate have increased. We downgrade NAVs by ~10%. We turn more negative on City Office and Retail exposures. CLS, Workspace and St Modwen screen as oversold and comprise higher risk picks. Defensive, structural growers still offer the safest combination of return vs. risk favouring storage and industrial. Assura, PHP and Shaftesbury are safe havens.

11:55 am
BE

10% NAV downgrades

The last three real estate corrections (exc. the GFC) prompted an avg. 4% fall in property values. This forms our initial assessment of a likely correction in UK real estate, prompting ~10% NAV downgrades.

The UK cycle is not over. Brexit needn’t be more painful. However, greater occupier uncertainty in London City Offices and Retail prompts downgrades for British Land (Sell), Land Securities (Sell), Intu (Sell) and Hammerson (Hold).

BE

While risks are higher, economic stabilisers and the adverse consequence of low interest rates will continue to support asset values. A disconnect with bond yields, weaker Sterling, lower financial risk and inflation hedge characteristics will all help perpetuate an expensive asset class relative to its income and risk.

BE

Significant headline NAV discounts are at face value appealing. The likelihood of M&A is also greater given Sterling weakness. However, we expect a prolonged period of occupier uncertainty, which will constrain rental growth and limit re-rating potential. Our key ratings remain weighted to the defensive structural growers.
